dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the Millennium Development Goals really did drive a lot of progress against HIV, especially in developing countries.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the Millennium Development Goals really did drive a lot of progress against H I V, especially in developing countries.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since the turn of the century, many of the advances against HIV were enabled by the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), a 15-year policy roadmap that made reducing the spread of the virus a top priority. This led to an unprecedented expansion of prevention and treatment services, particularly in developing countries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, but then when the Sustainable Development Goals took over in 2016, ending AIDS became just one of 169 targets—it's not a standalone priority anymore.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, but then when the Sustainable Development Goals took over in twenty sixteen, ending A I D S became just one of one hundred sixty nine targets-it's not a standalone priority anymore.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Progress was swift and when the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) succeeded the MDGs in 2015, ending AIDS was no longer a standalone goal. Rather, further progress had become one of 169 targets that the SDGs are supposed to achieve by 2030.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, and that shift has kind of lulled people into thinking we're almost done with AIDS, which is uh, dangerously misleading.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, and that shift has kind of lulled people into thinking we're almost done with A I D S, which is uh, dangerously misleading.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the transition from a goal to a target, combined with steep declines in AIDS-related deaths, has lulled us into a false sense of accomplishment. Today, many argue that AIDS is nearing its end.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's not just a biomedical issue either—like, access to medicine isn't enough if social or political barriers exist.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's not just a biomedical issue either-like, access to medicine isn't enough if social or political barriers exist.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Biomedical responses are vital to disease control, but if people cannot access medicine or preventive services, even the best-designed initiatives will fail. Whats more, the obstacles to treatment often have nothing to do with health care, but rather, are tied to political, economic, and social marginalization.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For example, gender inequality can make it nearly impossible for women to protect themselves from HIV in some regions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For example, gender inequality can make it nearly impossible for women to protect themselves from H I V in some regions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, it can be difficult to lower rates of infection in countries where gender inequality prevents women from making decisions about when, where, and even with whom they have sex.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And that recent situation in Zanzibar—where LGBT groups were targeted—shows how human rights violations directly threaten HIV prevention efforts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that recent situation in Zanzibar-where L G B T groups were targeted-shows how human rights violations directly threaten H I V prevention efforts.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, just last month in Tanzania, hundreds of lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) people were forced into hiding after a city official in Dar es Salaam warned that a taskforce was being created to identify and punish gay people.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's not an isolated case either; the Middle East and North Africa face similar issues with coercion and violence increasing women's risk.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's not an isolated case either; the Middle East and North Africa face similar issues with coercion and violence increasing women's risk.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On the contrary, as a recent report by my organization highlights, the situation is especially dire in the Middle East and North Africa, where forced sex within and outside of marriage is pervasive. These coercive and often violent encounters increase womens risk of exposure to HIV.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So if we're serious about ending AIDS, we have to integrate HIV strategies with broader sustainable development—things like poverty reduction and education.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So if we're serious about ending A I D S, we have to integrate H I V strategies with broader sustainable development-things like poverty reduction and education.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Only by linking HIV strategies to the issues that predispose people to infection such as poverty, education, and gender bias can we hope for a future free from AIDS for everyone, everywhere.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Because HIV rates are still highest among marginalized groups, which means as long as the SDGs aren't met, ending AIDS will stay out of reach.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Because H I V rates are still highest among marginalized groups, which means as long as the SDGs aren't met, ending A I D S will stay out of reach.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Today, HIV infection rates are highest among the poor and socially marginalized, underscoring the fact that as long as the SDGs are unmet, the goal of ending the scourge of HIV/AIDS will remain elusive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: The mantra is "leave no one behind," but right now, the most vulnerable are being forgotten.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The mantra is leave no one behind, but right now, the most vulnerable are being forgotten.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The mantra of the SDGs is leave no one behind. At the moment, however, many of those most vulnerable to HIV are being forgotten and will be left behind.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Activists have been pushing for years to address these interconnected challenges—repealing discriminatory laws, improving sexual health education…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Activists have been pushing for years to address these interconnected challenges-repealing discriminatory laws, improving sexual health education...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That is why activists have spent years working to repeal discriminatory laws, develop education programs to improve sexual and reproductive health, and build networks of supporters who understand that HIV does not discriminate by nationality, sexuality, or economic status.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But we've got a long way to go before everyone, everywhere, can live free from AIDS.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But we've got a long way to go before everyone, everywhere, can live free from A I D S.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We have a long way to go before that happens.
